case_name: Vishwabharti Insurance Company, Bombay, Damji Valji Shah and Jayantilal Hirijibhai Chawda v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 676 and 677 of 1962 filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 27, 1960 of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur in Case No. 30 XII of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 676 and 677 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 2,7. 1960 of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur in Case No. 30 XII of 1959.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation of India applied under s.15 of LIC Act to Tribunal against Vishwabharti Insurance Company and its directors for Rs.82,000 plus 6% interest from September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals, by special leave, are against the decree of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur, in proceedings on an application by the Life Insurance Corporation of India  hereinafter called the Corporation  under s. 15 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956  Act XXXI of 1956 , shortly termed as the LIC Act, for ordering the Vishwabharti Insurance Company, Bombay. Damji Valji Shah and Jayantilal Hirijibhai Chawda, appellants in the C.A. 676 of 1962, Ghanshyamdas, appellant in C.A. 677 of 1962, the aforementioned individuals being directors of the Vishwabharti Insurance Company, and another director, to pay to the Corporation jointly and severally the sum of Rs. 82,000/- together with interest there at 6 per annum from September 1, 1956, till full payment.

facts.text: Tribunal decreed company and directors (respondents 1 to 4) to pay Rs.82,000 plus interest to Corporation; company did not appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The decree ordered the companypany to pay a further sum. but we are number companycerned with that part of the decree as the companypany has number appealed against it.

facts.text: Vishwabharti Insurance Company was a composite insurer carrying life insurance and other classes of insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case briefly are these. The companypany was a companyposite insurer. i.e., an insurer who carried on. in addition to life insurance business. other classes of-insurance business.

facts.text: LIC Act came into force on July 1, 1956; Corporation established on September 1, 1956 (appointed day).

anchor.surface_text: The LIC Act came into force on july 1. 1956 and the Corporation was established on September 1. 1956 which was the appointed day according to s. 2 1  of that Act.

facts.text: On September 1, 1956, all assets and liabilities of life insurance business transferred to Corporation per s.7 LIC Act.

anchor.surface_text: On that day. in view of s. 7. all the assets and liabilities appertaining to the life insurance business  called the companytrolled business, vide s. 2 3   of the Company stood transferred to and vested in the Corporation.

facts.text: Rs.82,000 transferred from Life Insurance Fund to General Department not in accordance with Insurance Act 1938.

anchor.surface_text: It was found that certain amounts which had been transferred from the Life Insurance Fund in the books of the companypany to the General Department had number been transferred in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act 1938  Act 4 of 1938  which governed the companypany and should have companytinued to be included in the assets appertaining to the companytrolled business of the companypany.

facts.text: By resolution dated December 18, 1948, Rs.1,10,000 transferred from General Department to Life Department as advance, no interest, repay only from valuation surplus.

anchor.surface_text: By resolution dated December 18, 1948. Rs. 1.10.000/- were transferred from the General Department to the Life Department as advance to the Life Department Revenue Account for being added to the Life Fund. subject to the companydition that the Life Department would number be liable to pay any interest thereon and that numberrepayment of the lcan would be made except out of the valuation surplus of the Life Department.

facts.text: First actuarial valuation report for 1944-48 dated July 18, 1949: net liability Rs.6,55,718; Life Fund Rs.6,57,450; surplus Rs.1,732.

anchor.surface_text: The first actuarial valuation report of the companypany for the year 1944 -48. dated July 18 1949, showed that the net liability of the companypany was Rs. 6,55,7 18/and that the amount in the Life Fund was Rs. 6,57,450/and therefore the fund showed a surplus of Rs. 1,732/- over the net liabilities.

facts.text: Without Rs.1,10,000 transfer before Dec 31, 1948, valuation would show net liability exceeding Life Fund by about a lakh.

anchor.surface_text: If the sum of Rs. 1,10,000/- had number been transferred to the Life Department Revenue Account prior to December 31, 1948, this valuation report would have shown the net liability exceeding the amount in the life fund by about a lakh of rupees.

facts.text: Profit Loss Appropriation Account 1949: Rs.60,000 out of Rs.1,10,000 written off.

anchor.surface_text: The Profit Loss Appropriation Account for the year 1949 shows that Rs. 60,000/- out of this amount of Rs. 1,10,000/- was written off as the companypany had made profits.

facts.text: Rs.32,000 transferred to Life Fund from General Department with retrospective effect from December 31, 1952 per resolution August 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 32,000/- were again similarly transferred to the Life Fund from the General Department with retrospective effect from December 31, 1952 in order to strengthen the position of the Life Fund. The second actuarial valuation report for the period 1949-52, dated September 9, 1953, showed that the policy liability amounted to Rs. 15,3,3,068, that the Life Fund stood at Rs. 15,35,890/- and that thus the Life Fund exceeded the net liability by Rs. 2,822/-.

facts.text: Second actuarial valuation 1949-52 dated September 9, 1953: policy liability Rs.15,33,068; Life Fund Rs.15,35,890; surplus Rs.2,822.

anchor.surface_text: The second actuarial valuation report for the period 1949-52, dated September 9, 1953, showed that the policy liability amounted to Rs. 15,3,3,068, that the Life Fund stood at Rs. 15,35,890/- and that thus the Life Fund exceeded the net liability by Rs. 2,822/-

facts.text: Resolution dated January 6, 1956: Rs.82,000 transferred from Life Fund to General Department; balance Rs.60,000 kept in reserve.

anchor.surface_text: It was this amount of Rs. 82,000/- Rs. 50,000,- plus Rs. 32,000/-  which, by a resolution dated January 6. 1956 was transferred to the General Department from the Life Fund. The resolution reads Resolved that a loan of Rs. 82,000/-  eighty two thousand only  advanced to Life Department Revenue Account by General Department be and is hereby repaid to Genera1 Department and the balance of Rs. 60,000/- due to General Department by Life Department Revenue Account be and is hereby kept in reserve for future and hence numberadjustment in regard to Rs. 60,000/- will be made for the present.

facts.text: Resolution of January 6, 1956 confirmed by Board on February 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution was companyfirmed by the Board of Directors at its meeting dated February 6, 1956.

facts.text: Life Insurance Emergency Provisions Ordinance, 1956 promulgated January 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: We may number refer to the changes in law with respect to life insurance business in 1956 and an anticipation of which probably led to the resolution of January 6, 1956. On January 19, 1956, the Life Insurance  Emergency Provisions  Ordinance, 1956  Ord. No. 1 of 1956  was promulgated by the President.

facts.text: Directors Damji Valji Shah, Jayantilal Hirijibhai Chawda, Ghanshyamdas were parties to resolutions.

anchor.surface_text: Ghanshyamdas and Damji Valji were also parties to the resolution dated February 7. 1956. Other directors who were parties to the resolution of January 6 were also impleaded.

facts.text: Directors contested: transfer was repayment of loan when Life Fund showed surplus per actuary report July 25, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid three directors, the appellants before us, companytested the claim of the Corporation and justified the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department from the Life Fund on the ground that the amount had been lent by the General Department to the Life Department and had been paid back to the General Department by transfer from the Life Fund when the LifE Fund showed surplus, according to the report of the Actuary dated July 25, 1955.

facts.text: Tribunal held transfers of Rs.1,10,000 and Rs.32,000 not loans; Rs.82,000 transfer not from valuation surplus, invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the amounts of Rs. 1,10,000/- and Rs. 30,000/- were number advanced to the Life Department as loans and that the transfer of Rs. 82.000/- was number out of the valuation surplus and that therefore the transfer of this amount companyld number be said to be for companysideration and necessary or reasonably necessary for the purpose of the companytrolled business of the companypany or even a prudent transaction having regard to the interest of the life policy holders.

facts.text: Vishwabharti Insurance Company ordered to be wound up by Bombay High Court on November 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: the companypany having been ordered to be wound-up by the High Court on November 9, 1959,

facts.text: Actuary letter July 25, 1955: policy liability Rs.20,20,421; Life Fund Rs.21,32,455; surplus Rs.1,12,033 (net working Rs.58,733 after appreciation).

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this companynection is placed on behalf of the appellants on the letter of the actuary dated July 25, 1955. The actuary states On the above basis, the valuation shows a policy liability of Rs. 20,20,421. The Life Insurance Fund is Rs. 21,32,455. Thus there is a surplus of Rs. 1.12.033.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal had jurisdiction despite winding up; s.446 Companies Act and s.44 LIC Act not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to companytinue the proceedings after November 9, 1959 when the companypany was ordered to be wound-up and that the provisions of s. 446, Companies Act, or s. 44 a , LIC Act, do number in any way affect its jurisdiction to companytinue the proceedings.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed transfers not loans; Rs.82,000 belonged to life insurance assets vested in Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a companyrect view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was number in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that companysequently that amount companytinued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal had no jurisdiction to proceed with the proceedings on the petition presented by the Corporation without the leave of the High Court in view of s. 446 of the Companies Act, 1956, the company having been ordered to be wound-up by the High Court on November 9, 1959

anchor.surface_text: i  The Tribunal had numberjurisdiction to proceed with the proceedings on the petition presented by the Corporation without the leave of the High Court in view of s. 446 of the Companies Act, 1956, the companypany having been ordered to be wound-up by the High Court on November 9, 1959,

issues.text: Whether in view of s. 44(a) of the LIC Act none of the provisions of the Act applied to the company and therefore the Tribunal could not proceed on the application of the Corporation subsequent to the company being wound-up

anchor.surface_text: ii  In view of s. 44 a  of the LIC Act numbere of the provisions of the Act applied to the companypany and therefore the Tribunal companyld number proceed on the application of the Corporation subsequent to the companypany being wound-up.

issues.text: Whether the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from the Life Fund to the General Department of the company was for consideration and was necessary for the life insurance business

anchor.surface_text: iii  The transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from the Life Fund to the General Department of the companypany was for companysideration and was necessary for the life insurance business.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 15(1)(f) of the LIC Act were ultra vires as they contravened the provisions of Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The fourth point sought to be urged was that the provisions of s. 15 1  f  of the LIC Act were ultra rites as they companytravened the provisions of Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from the Life Fund to the General Department was without consideration or for inadequate consideration, not reasonably necessary for the controlled business or made with unreasonable lack of prudence

anchor.surface_text: companytended that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- from the Life Fund to the General Department under the resolution of January 6, 1956, was illegal. being companytrary to and in companytravention of the insurance Act and as such was inoperative, bad in law and number binding on the petitioner. It was further companytended that the said transfer was without companysideration

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the Tribunal that the amounts of Rs. 1.10,000/-and Rs. 32,000/- were number lent to the Life Department as such by the General Department.

anchor.surface_text: It was out of such surplus that the companypany resolved that the advances of Rs. 1,10,000/and Rs. 32,000/- companyld be paid to the General Department by the Life Department. No such actuarial valuation was made by the actuary prior to the transfer

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether these provisions would affect the proceedings of the Tribunal. In this companynection, reference may be made to s. 41 of the LIC Act which provides that numbercivil Court shall have jurisdiction

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with Tribunal; transfers not loans, not from valuation surplus per Insurance Act s.13; amount vested in Corporation per s.7 LIC

arguments.claim: The amounts Rs.1,10,000 and Rs.32,000 were loans from General to Life Department, repaid Rs.82,000 from Life Fund when surplus per actuary report July 25, 1955

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid three directors, the appellants before us, contested the claim of the Corporation and justified the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department from the Life Fund on the ground that the amount had been lent by the General

arguments.court_reasoning: No lending between departments possible; conduct (write-off) shows not loans; not repaid from proper valuation surplus per s.13 Insurance Act Form I; actuary letter not statutory valuation

arguments.claim: Life Fund assets per s.10 Insurance Act solely for policyholders, cannot be transferred except per Act

anchor.surface_text: The company had to keep separate accounts of all receipts and payments in respect of each class of insurance business. in view of s. 10 1  of the Insurance Act.

holdings.text: The Tribunal had jurisdiction to continue the proceedings after November 9, 1959 when the company was ordered to be wound-up and the provisions of s. 446, Companies Act, or s. 44(a), LIC Act, do not in any way affect its jurisdiction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 LIC Act bars civil court jurisdiction including company court over Tribunal matters; special Act (LIC) overrides general Companies Act; company not 'insurer' under s.2(6) LIC post-appointed day.

holdings.text: s.44(a) of the LIC Act does not apply to bar Tribunal proceedings as company was not being wound up when Act came into force or on appointed day and ceased to be 'insurer' carrying life business thereafter.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applicability of s.44(a) determined at time LIC Act effective or appointed day; company not wound up then; post s.7 transfer, not insurer per s.2(6) as no life business.

holdings.text: The amounts of Rs.1,10,000/- and Rs.32,000/- were not lent to the Life Department as loans by the General Department.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No inter-departmental lending possible; resolutions conditional no interest/repay only from surplus; conduct (partial write-off Rs.60,000) shows augmentation/deposits to meet s.10 Insurance Act Life Fund requirements for policyholders.

holdings.text: The transfer of Rs.82,000/- from Life Fund to General Department was not out of valuation surplus and not in accordance with Insurance Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuation surplus technical per s.13 Insurance Act, Form I (statutory triennial valuation submitted to Controller); July 1955 actuary letter not such, net working surplus only Rs.58,733 < Rs.82,000; appreciation excluded.

holdings.text: The transfer of Rs.82,000/- was without consideration, not reasonably necessary for controlled business, imprudent; continued as life assets vesting in Corporation under s.7 LIC Act; directors liable jointly and severally.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not loans/not surplus per Insurance Act ss.10,13; Life Fund assets solely for policyholders s.10(3); contravened s.15 LIC criteria; vested in LIC s.7; affirms Tribunal decree.

holdings.text: Provisions of Companies Act s.446 do not affect Tribunal proceedings due to s.41 LIC Act exclusive jurisdiction.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 excludes civil courts; company court not empowered over special Tribunal jurisdiction under LIC Act.

holdings.text: LIC Act as special Act overrides Companies Act as general Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: special prevails over general.

holdings.text: Valuation surplus means surplus in Form I of Fourth Schedule per s.13 Insurance Act (net liability vs Life Fund balance post-statutory actuarial investigation).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Technical definition from statutory forms for triennial valuation abstract submitted to Controller.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation which could recover it from the companypany and the directors responsible for the transfer of the amount to the General Department.

outcome.relief_summary: Tribunal's decree upheld; transfer of Rs. 82,000/- held invalid and part of life insurance assets vested in Corporation which could recover it from company and directors

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation which could recover it from the companypany and the directors responsible for the transfer of the amount to the General Department.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation which could recover it from the companypany and the directors responsible for the transfer of the amount to the General Department.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation which could recover it from the companypany and the directors responsible for the transfer of the amount to the General Department.

We are therefore of opinion that the Tribunal took a correct view about the nature of the transfer of Rs. 1,10,000/- in 1948 and Rs. 32,000/- in 1952 to the Life Insurance Fund and rightly held that the transfer of Rs. 82,000/- to the General Department by resolution dated January 6, 1956, was not in accordance with the provisions of the Insurance Act and that consequently that amount continued to form part of the assets of the life insurance business of the companypany upto September 1, 1956 and that as such vested in the Corporation which could recover it from the companypany and the directors responsible for the transfer of the amount to the General Department.
